div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

MONDAY. FEBRUARY 27, 1905.

div.head: The Railway Report.
div.p: As stated in our columns on Saturday, the report of the Railway Commission on the Egyptian State Railways is given to the public in its entirety. In reviewing this elab= orate and comprehensive report it naturally occurs to us that our railways lend themselves to, and possibly invite, criticism to an extent which would apply to hardly any other Department of State. How some others would have stood the searching ordeal to which the railways have been subjected, we do not venture to guess, and that it would have been possible for any chief or chiefs to have effected the improvements in the railways, which have been carried out, for instance, in the Customs Administration, is another question on which we do not venture to give an opinion ; but it is noteworthy that the opportunity, which has presented itself to the public, does not seem to have been taken advantage of to complain, as would have been in conformity therewith, if they had considered themselves badly served. The work we enter upon is facilitated by our ready acceptance of the commissioners’ report as an outspoken and unvarnished tale given to us in extenso by the authorities. The omission of reference to the personnel becomes Intelligible as we study the report, its subject and its surrounding circumstances, but we do not, for an instant, suppose that the commissioners shirked this part of the duties entrusted to them. The report commences by recapitulating the instructions conveyed to the Commissioners by the Adviser. All that need be said of those is that they were clear and compre- hensive, evidently showing a desire that the work should be thoroughly done and fully reported upon. The appointments to the commission were carefully made with the same objects and, when one considers the varied qualifications and experience of those gentlemen and the reputations they enjoy where they are best known, we are inclined to think better selections could not have been made. On their part the commissioners showed their earnestness in the work by proceeding at once, upon landing, to see things for themselves, and to gain all the information they could. We have it from the report that they inspected every yard of the lines, and, from our own knowledge, that in this town they went over the whole of the railway premises (including Gabhari and its new shuntiug yard), the port, etc, entertained some of our leading merchants to dinner, and spent a morning with our Chamber of Commerce,—not a bad record for two days' work, and we have no reason to believe that they were less energetic elsewhere. It is a great thing to know that the work was thus dealt with, even hurriedly.

The first conclusion arrived at by the Com- mission is that the general management of the railways is unsatisfactory, and that this is due to the system in force. Of all things in the world, the immediate charge of a rail- way is admittedly the work of one man; and so it is, everywhere but in Egypt, that the success or failure of a line, or system of lines, is placed to the account of the man in supreme charge. There are those who succeed and draw the high salaries they deserve, and those who have failed and been paid highly to go. In this country we have, instead, a body of three, all of different nationalities and, perhaps more unfortunately still, all exceedingly able men. Apparently their respective duties and powers are as undefined as they are limited by circumstances, and we do not even gather that the Chairman has power of veto or any other special authority. Coupled with this fact, it is within the knowledge of all that the Government and the Caisse de la Dette ex- ercise separate powers, and that all sorts of political reasons, local laws, and customs tend to increase the difficulties of management. We have no desire to defend anybody or anything, but the public have, we think, some reason to be thankful that, instead of a deadlock having been ever arrived at, considerable progress and improvements have of late years been effected. We can all remember when the journey between Alexandria and Cairo was made under very different conditions to those existing at pre- sent. We are glad to see the acknowledgment of the improved punctuality of the passenger train service, and we can add to this ours of the increased comfort and security of travel- ling. The commissioners state that it has been impossible "to work these railways on good commercial lines” and that the conditions are "heart-breaking" to those concerned and int- erested in the work. Close attention to one's duties under such circumstances is much to be admired, and we know of many in their differ- ent positions who are entitled to great praise on this account, as well as to apologies for criticisms which have been unfairly levelled at them.

We come now to the remedy: one general manager with the powers be would possess anywhere else. The report does not say if such a man is to be found on the railways, or is to be a new importation. It does not either enter into the question whether such powers can or cannot be given to a single individual (however fit for his position) in this country, or whether, in fact, his duties can be similar to those of a general manager elsewhere, owing to the differ- ence in conditions which must exist between a State railway in this country and an railway in any other. Those are all questions which the commissioners evidently did not consider immediately dominated them or their recommendations for the future, and we cannot say that our view is different, but we can realise that the Government might have liked something easier to solve than a recommendation in terms such as these Above such general manager, a State Council is proposed. The idea is excellent, we even trust it is practicable. The difficulty we foresee is that the members must have some leisure to give to their important though occasional duties and not enough to devote to worrying. the general manager or to submitting to worries from him or caused by him. The commissioners were all men well versed in successful business and company management, and doubtless their model was a good board of directors such as they are accustomed to work with, and holding powers extending to the promotion of the fit and the removal of offenders. Under the general manager there would be the usual departments and the head of each would be responsible for its organisation and working. Given the necessary qualifications in such chiefs, and following on the same lines of giving to all of these the powers and respon- sibilities conferred upon them everywhere but in Egypt, the working of the machinery may be said to be completely and satisfactorily provided for: the rest is mere detail. Of course, even the most able and energetic head of a department cannot do everything himself, and the Egyptians are to be trained for higher posts, so we must take it to mean, that all heads are to be supported by sufficient trained assistants. The fact that salaries are too low has been recognised. Such could not well have escaped the notice of railway men from England, India, and South America. With increased pay (which must be sufficiently general) more laborious duties and more eff- icient performance of them can be exacted, the machine need not be left so much to itself in the hot weather, and there should not be the same number of whole and half holidays. We feel that this is a convenient point at which to bring the present article to a close, and in our next we shall consider the proposals as affecting the different departments.

div.head: The War
A DESPERATE BATTLE
JAPS CAPTURE POSITION
SUCCESSFUL BAYONET RUSH
div.p: ST. Petersburg February 25 The Japanese attack on Beresneff Hill during the night of the 23rd inst. was repulsed. it was, however, renewed yesterday, when the Russians were forced to retire. A desperate battle is proceeding along the whole front the result being indecisive. General Sakharoff reports that the railway bridge in the vicinity of Hai-Cheng has been blown up, thus interrupting the Japanese communications. (Reuter.)

TOKIO, February 25. The Russian attempt to blow up the bridge at Haicheng has been foiled by the arrival of Japanese reinforcements. The Russian cavalry is constantly active in the direction of Niu- clwang. (Reuter.)

ST. Petersburg, February 25. General Sakharoff reports that Beresneff was finally captured by a bayonet rush, the Japanese advancing over their own dead amid exploding mines and entanglements. The enemy lost a considerable number of men. (R.)
ST. Petersburg, February 25. General Sakharoff telegraphs that the Russians evacuated the position of Beresneff, ad¬ joining Tsinkhetehon. (Havas.)

ST. PETERSBURG, February 26. A despatch from General Kropotkin shows that the last day's fighting for the village of Tsinkhechen was most desperate. He reports a series of acts of bravery on the part of the Russians, who did not evacuate the position until their cartridges were exhausted. Their losses are still unknown, but 12 officers and 300 men have been taken to the hospital. The percentage of head is large. The Japanese are advancing on the passes held by the Russians. (Reuter.)

div.head: North Sea Enquiry
Rodjestvensky at Fault
div.p: Paris, Feburary 25. The text of the Commission's report bears evident signs of compromises. some of the passages are almost Contradictory, thus ac¬ counting for the misleading character of the previous anticipations. It says that Admiral Rodjestvensky's permanent orders to open fire “in case of are evident and immediate attack by torpedo-boats" were not excessive in time of war, and particularly in circumstances which the Admiral had reason to believe were alarming, hut the Commissioners find—Russia alone dissenting—there were no torpedo-boats present, at the time of the incident. The responsibility for opening fire and for the results devolves upon Rodjestvensky. The Commissioners believe that the Rus¬ sians neutrally tiled upon their own cruiser "Aurora," which they mistook for a torpedo- boat . The firing anyhow was unduly prolonged. Rodjestvensky ought to have informed the authorities of the occurrence when passing Dover. It concludes by stating that the report is not intended to disparage the capacity or humanity of Rodjestvensky. (Reuter.)

PARIS, February 25. At its final sitting, the North Sea Commis- sion concluded that Admiral Rodjestvensky was responsible for the firing and its conse¬ quences, but owing to circumstances the inci¬ dent does not in any way throw discredit on the military valour and the humanitarian sentiments of the Admiral and his squadron. (Havas.)

div.head: Third Baltic Fleet.
div.p: DOVER, February 25. The third Baltic squadron has passed off here. (Reuter.)

div.head: General Stoessel.
Received by the tsar.
div.p: St. Petersburg, February 26. The Tsar has recieved General Stoessel and gave him a warm reception. (Havas.)

div.head: Home Football.
div.p: LONDON, February 26. Rugby. Ireland beat Scotland by 11 points to 5. Association. England v. Ireland. One goal each. Queen’s Club. The Army beat the Navy by 2 goals to nil. The King and the Prince of Wales were present. (Reuter.)

div.head: ANARCHY IN CAUCASUS.
HORRIBLE ATROCITIES.
ARMED RISING PROGRESSING
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, February 25. The press states that the whole of Eastern Siberia, like the Caucasus, is virtually cutoff from Russia so fur as trade is concerned. The merchants and better classes are fleeing from Baku, where the riots are characterised as atrocities. Men and women have been burned alive, and corpses mutilated. An armed rising is progressing in the country districts of the Caucasus. (Reuter.)
WARSAW, February 25. The demands of the strikers on the Warsaw- Vienna Railway have been conceded by the Government Traffic is being resumed. (R.)

LONDON, February 25. Despatches from-Constantinople describe the whole Caucasus as being in a state of anarchy. There appears to be a general semi-revoln- tionary strike movement which is directed by a secret committee at St Petersburg. Added to this, ferocious racial feuds exist, and horrible atrocities are being perpetrated. (Reuter.)
WARSAW, February 25. The employes,on the Vienna-Warsaw Rail¬ way are not satisfied with the concessions and have re-struck. (Reuter.)

div.head: RUSSIAN CONSTITUTION.
An Absolute Necessity.
The Tsar's Decision.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, February 26. The Minister Yermuloff was engaged during the past week in preparing a long and detailed report on the inner situation of Russia. He presented it on Friday to the Tsar. This report, depicting in plain language the chaotic condition of Russia and indicating the danger of procrastination, shows the absolute neces¬ sity, in order to avert a revolution, of adopt¬ ing immediate drastic measures to meet the grave crisis. No reforms short of a Constitu¬ tion on western hues will satisfy the people and restore order. The Tsar has since directed steps to be taken with a view to summoning a representative assembly in order to draft a Constitution giving, in a large measure, re¬ presentative government. A meeting of Ministers and others yesterday, presided over by M. Yermoloff, discussed the steps to he taken in order to give the Tsar’s decision a practical form. The workmen in the railway shops at Chita on the Siberian line have struck. They demand a cessation of the war. (Reuter.)
ST. PETERSBURG, February 25. The Tsar has , approved the conclusions of the report of M. Yermoloff for the convocation of the National Assembly with the object of drawing up a Constitution. (Havas.)

div.head: Royal Visit to India.
div.p: LONDON, February 26. (Official). The Prince and Princess of Wales will arrive in India next November, and stay until the following March. They will visit the principal cities. ( Reuter.)

div.head: Railway Troubles in Italy.
div.p: ROME, February 26. The railway employes, without actually declaring a strike; are trying to impede the circulation of the trains. (Havas.)

div.head: Local and General
div.p: THE PLAGUE - A fatal case of plague was reported from Suez yesterday.

MERCHANT SEAMEN'S HOME.—In the report of the concert given on Friday last, the name of Mr. Plank, who. gave two admirable recita¬ tions,—Tennyson’s “Revenge” being particular¬ ly good,—was inadvertently omitted.

AMERICAN MISSION.—Miss Belle Kearney, of Mississippi, U. S. A., a national lecturer and writer for the W. C. T. U., is to give an address to-morrow at 3.30 p.m., in the American Mission Church, near Shepheard’s Hotel. All are welcome.

Y. W. C. A.—The concert at the Y.W.C.A, Cairo, to morrow promises to be a good one, as the following have kindly promised to help : Mme. Amster, Mrs. Archibald, Mrs. Elliot Smith, Dr. Stross, and Signor Valentino. The programme includes orchestral and vocal items.

THE HAMBURG AMERICAN LINE’S S. S. “ Moltke ” arrived at Alexandria this morning with a large number of tourists on board under the charge of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son. The visitors have left for Cairo and will spend twelve days in Egypt, going as tar as Assouan.

MASONIC MEETING.—We have been asked to announce that there will be an emergency meeting of the Raghen Lodge No. 51 Egyptian Constitution, at the' Masonic Hall, Boulac- road, on Tuesday at 9 p.m. precisely, to pass and raise a brother who is leaving for England at the end of the week.

COINERS RAIDED.—Miralai Hopkinson Bey and the Alexandria City Police are to be con¬ gratulated on having brought off a highly successful “coup” this morning. For some time past it had been known that a gang of coiners had established themselves in Alexandria, and the police have accordingly been on the look¬ out. At last a raid was made this morning on a house in Karmous and two coiners were found hard at work turning out English sove¬ reigns and floriusand Egyptian dollars. The coining plant was most elaborate, and the various coins were found in the dies and in other stages of manufacture. The two men are Greek local subjects and are believed to have come from Mansourah. The coins were sent to the villages. Some of the coins found this morning were so well made that they have a distinct ring.

SUEZ E.T.C.-STAFF MESS “AT HOME." — The visit of the C. S. “Electra” to Suez was the occasion of an “at home” given by the mem- ber's of the E.T.C. Staff Mess on Wednesday last. The function was well attended and dancing was indulged in by the numerous invites.” The quarters had been suitably transformed for the occasion, and the artistic taste exhibited by the members of the mess in the decoration of the rooms would have done credit to many of the fairer sex. After supper the guests were treated to some songs Mr. H. T. Heale’s splendid baritone voice was shown to full advantage in “Nirvana," a song thoroughly appreciated by the listeners, and “My Toreador,” sweetly sung by Mrs. Scott, deserved in every Way the applause it received. The singers were ably accompanied by Mrs. Tillard. Before dancing was resumed Mr. O. D. Harris gave some original im¬ personations of the popular conjurer, juggler, and “strong man" of the London music hall stage. On leaving, the guests were unanimous in their expressions of thanks and enjoyment to the members of the E.T.C. Staff Mess, whose entertainments and hospitality are a feature of life iu Suez

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL SOCIETY.
div.p: The annual general meeting of the members of the A. H. S. will be held to-morrow at 6 p.m. at the offices of Messrs. Carver Bros. and Co., Ltd. In their report to the members, the committee state that the Agricultural Depart¬ ment of the United. States' kindly presented the society with several fruit trees, such as oranges, plums, and peaches, with the object of improving the stock already existing in the country, but although the packing was carefully executed the long sea journey was clearly detrimental to the plants and only two Navel oranges and one Homosassa blood orange have survived. These, however, are healthy plants and it is hoped that, in a year or two, it will be possible to offer members shoots for grafting. The disease that has attacked the orange trees has by no means disappeared ; and the committee understand that besides the oranges and bananas, the figs, grapes and dates also show signs of scale and other parasites which are detrimental to their proper development It is therefore with pleasure that the committee have heard that the Khedivial Agricultural Society has appoint¬ ed an export to study the cause and effect of the different diseases which have appeared in the country. The best proof of the continued popularity of the society's shows is that every year more space is required; Besides the Casino at San Stefano, which was again kindly placed at the disposal of the committee by the Nungovich Hotels Co., it was necessary last spring to add four large tents, being one more than in 1903, and in the autumn the exhibits were found to be too numerous for the ball-room and the cut flowers had consequently to be placed in the large reading-room. Besides two Princes of the Khedivial family there are now 114 members of the society. The accounts for the past year show a balance of P.T. 3,902.5, besides £200 Egyptian Unified Debt deposited at the Bank of Egypt.

div.head: ROYAL BETROTHAL IN CAIRO.
PRINCESS MARGARET TO MARRY PRINCE GUSTAVUS ADOLPHUS.
div.p: We are authorised to announce that H.R.H. Princess Margaret of Connaught has been betrothed to H.R.H. Prince Gustavus Adol- phus of Sweden and Norway. The betrothal of Princess Margaret of Con- naught to Prince Gustavus Adolphus had been surmised in some of the London newspapers, but was categorically denied in “Truth,” which stated that there was a project of marriage between the Prince and Princess Olga of Ha ¬nover, third daughter of the Duke of Cumber¬ land. The Prince was born on November 11, 1882, and is the eldest son of the Crown Prince of Sweden and Norway, and in the ordinary course of things will one day become King. Princess Margaret of Connaught was born on January 15, 1882, so is ten months the senior of her future husband.

div.head: The Royal Visit.
div.p: H. R. H. the Duchess of Connaught visited the Anglo-American Hospital on Saturday afternoon, in company with Lady Cromer. The distinguished visitors were met at the door by the members of the house com¬ mittee and the honorary medical staff, and were shown over the hospital by the matron, Miss Arbuthnot. T. R.H. the Duke and Duchess of Con- uaught, Prince Gustavus Adolphus of Sweden and Norway, and the Princesses Margaret and Patricia attended divine service at All Saints’ Church, Cairo, yesterday morning. The Royal party will leave Cairo for Alex- andria at 2 p.m. to-morrow by the Khedive’s state train. H. H. the Khedive will himself be present at the station to say farewell to their Royal Highnesses, and among others who will be present will be Lord Cromer, the various Diplomatic Agents for the Powers, Major- General Slade, C.B., and the Headquarters Staff of the British and Egyptian Armies, etc. The Royal party will detrain at the Arsenal wharf and proceed on board H. M. S. “Essex,” where they will remain for the night.

div.head: BRITISH GARRISON.
div.p: It is reported that the headquarters and half of the 1st Battalion of the King’s Royal Rifle Corps is coming here early in March from Malta. The 56th Battery R.F.A. will leave Alexan- dria by the transport "Dilwara" on the 4th proxo. for England.

div.head: DEATH OF HAICALIS PASHA.
DOYEN OF THE LOCAL PRBSS.
div.p: It is with the deepest regret that we have to announce the death of the “doyen" of the Egyptian Press, his Excellency Dr. Haicalis Pasha, Editor-proprietor of the “Phared’Alexan- drie. The Pasha, who had been ill for some weeks, breathed his last yesterday evening at 5.50 o clock. The funeral will take place this afternoon at 4 o'clock. Nicolas Haicalis pasha was born at Zante on the 29th May, 1836. He was educated at Athens and afterwards at Turin, where he resided with the family of Count Santa Rosa, who died at Sphacteria fighting for the independence of Greece. He obtained the degree of Doctor of. Law at Turin University and returned in 1860 to Greece, where he joined the Athenian Bar. Before he had begun to practise at the Bar, he made the acquaintance of the manager of the Daira of Prince Ahmed Pasha, and was invited by him to visit Egypt He did so, and was shortly afterwards appointed counsel to the Daira Ahmed Pasha at a salary of L.E. 60 a month. On the Khedive Ismail succeeding to the Viceroyship, Haicalis was appointed counsel to the Azezieh Steam Navigation Company. In this position he initiated a permanent steam¬ ship service between the Piraens and Egypt Formerly the direct route from Alexandria to Athens was by way of Corfu or Smyrna. Haicalis was soon afterwards appointed coun- sel to the Customs Administration, the Rail- way Administration, and other Government departments, and enjoyed a high position at the local Bar. In 1869 he went to Venice to start a direct service between Venice and Alex¬ andria, and there made the acquaintance of Mr. Cook, the founder of the great tourist agency, which in those days was, it is needless to say, by no means the gigantic organisation which it is now. It is said that Haicalis was the first to persuade Mr. Cook to come to Egypt and start his business here, which has since developed into the firm of Thos. Cook & Son (Egypt), Limited. The Press in Egypt was in those days far worse than it is now, and the newspapers levied blackmail on a very extensive scale. Ismail tried to put an end to this abase, which had become a public scandal, and commanded Haicalis to establish a newspaper which would have some regard for journalistic decency. A con¬ tract was made between the Ministry for Foreign Affairs and Haicalis in 1873, and this was the beginning of the “Phare d’Alexandrie." The Khedive granted the paper a considerable subvention, and the “Phared’Alexandrie" soon became, under the editorship of Haicalis, one of the leading journals in Egypt When Ismail abdicated, the contract between the Egyptian Government and the “Phare d'Alaxandrie” not renewed. Haicalis, however, de- termined to run the paper without a sub¬ vention, and for some time lost 35,000 francs per annum in the attempt But he persevered and in a comparatively short space of time the “Phare” brought in a substantial yearly profit to its proprietor of 50,000 francs. The Pasha was Officer of the Order of the Saviour,of the Order of the Crown of Italy,and of the Legion of Honor, and held high Egyptian honors and decorations. The deceased, who had been a widower for some years, leaves a son and four daughters to mourn his loss. We beg to tender our deepest sympathy to the family of the Pasha in their irreparable bereavement. The death of Dr. Haicalis Pasha removes the best-known figure in the European Press of Egypt, and we deeply regret the loss of an upright and conscientious confrere.

div.head: MAITRE-ALBRECHT'S ACCIDENT.
div.p: We are glad to hear that Maltre Albrecht is still making favorable progress towards reco¬ very. We have received the following version of the accident that befell him from reliable source. Maltre Albrecht was returning from Tantah in the company of Mr. Lee and Mr. Xenos at the time of the accident The light in the carriage being bad, his two companions were sitting at each corner at the opposite end of the carriage trying to read. Maltre Albrecht, who had a newspaper, stood up by the door of the carriage to get the light behind him. Putting back his hands to steady himself, he caught hold of the door, which had not been fastened, and fell on to the railway. His two companions immediately sought for the com- munication cord, and found that there was none. They then attempted to get to the next carriage, along the footboard, but the speed of the train and the absence of any hand rails made it impossible. At Mansourah they got out and demanded donkeys, which were not to be had, and wired to the station master of the station which they had left, i.e., Samanoud. They were not a little relieved to get an answering wire that Maitre Albrecht had walked into the station with his head cut, but with no further injury. As a matter of fact Maltre Albrecht had been picked up un- conscious on the permanent way. When his friends came to meet him, they found no traces of him, and after waiting for some time were informed that he had been sent to hos¬ pital in the train. Assuming that bo had been sent up to Cairo, they followed there, only to find that he had been sent to Tantah hospital. The unfortunate gentleman received first aid at Samanoud from a Greek doctor. Madame Albrecht immediately hurried down to Tantah and found her husband lying in the hospital with his head bandaged. Apparently nothing else had been done by the doctor responsible for the case, and Mme Albrecht promptly brought her husband back to Cairo.

div.head: Notes from Port Said.
A nondescript vessel.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT). . Port Said, Saturday. A vessel bearing the name of “Malaya” arrived from the canal this morning at 6.25, but of what nature this boat is it is difficult to say without jumping to conclusions, owing-to the peculiar and various characteristics she presented. The remarkable facts about this vessel are, that she is flying the Russian com¬ mercial flag, her funnel is pointed in Russian commercial colours, her sides are of the same co¬ lour as those of the Russian Volunteer Fleet, her officers are German, her deck crew is Russian, she is fitted up as a hospital ship, her passengers consist of wounded Russians, and the man in charge,who can neither be described as a captain or as a supercargo, is a Russian naval officer.

div.head: Russian Torpedo Boat.
div.p: The Russian torpedo boat "Rezvoy” also arrived from the canal this morning some three- and-a-half hours later. She is one of the torpedo boats which escaped from Port Arthur, and she is being supplied with coal by the “Malaya." The canal tonnage of the "Rezvoy” is registered as 103 tons and that of the "Malaya” as 3,530 tons, and the cargo of the latter is declared as 150 tons coal and various.

div.head: Rissian Colliers
div.p: The Danish steamer “Powell Andrejeff" arrived here last night and adds one more vessel to the present contingent of 14 Russian colliers, some of which have been lying here awaiting orders for as much as two months. The very: great majority of these boats are German, and are chartered by the Hamburg-American Company.

div.head: The sinking of the "congal"
div.p: It is semiofficially announced that an agree¬ ment has been made between the underwriters of the Norwegian steamer “Congal,” which it will be remembered was sunk at anchor by the Harrison Line S.S. "Craftsman” some ten days ago, and the Constantinople Salvage Associa¬ tion, by which the latter agree, on the no-cure- no-pay principle, to salve the vessel and her cargo entire. Since the “Congal” was sunk she has set bodily into the mud for consider¬ ably over a foot and a half and her position remains the same. The divers now report that almost her entire main-deck has burst open, and there is no doubt that the beam ends have been torn away in very many places. The value of the hull is £11,500, for which sum she is insured, and that of the cargo may be estimated at about £4,500. The present intention is to try and lift her by means of the floating power of empty lighters, but in all probability this method will prove unsuccessful as the value of the power of the mud in which she is embedded is enormous. Should this attempt fail the hole in her side will be temporarily repaired, and a coffee-dam will be built entirely round her, and she will then be raised by means of pumps in exactly the same manner as the battleship which sunk in Gibraltar some two years ago. The success of such a method is fairly certain, as the "Congal” has only a displacement of 5,000 tons under her present conditions, and that of the battleship which was raised in this way was 13,000 tons.

div.head: Personal and Social.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive is giving a banquet on Monday next in honor of Major-General Slade, C.B., on the occasion of his approaching retire- ment.

A well-known figure in London society,who is at present staying at the Savoy Hotel, Assouan, is the Hon. Mrs. Ronald Greville. She was Miss Margaret Anderson, stepdaughter of Mr. William M’Ewan, a wealthy brewer, a Scotchman, and for many years a Liberal member for Edinburgh. Her marriage with (Captain Ronald Greville, elder son of Lord Greville, took place in 1871. Here is a case of the transformation that marriage so often effects in our modern upper- class woman. She was once a pleasant-faced "Sousie” Scotch maiden, but has been gradually transformed into a pretty and very smart married woman. Mrs.Greville has many friends, and gives some dinners and concerts in London. She also stands well at Court, has entertained King Edward at dinner and at week-end par¬ ties, and was one of the few fortunate ladies to receive an invitation to His Majesty's private box at the Coronation ceremony. Mr. M’Ewan has a box at the opera for every night in the week, and there Mrs. Greville may often be seen dressed and jewelled to perfection. Her devoted stepfather gives with a generous hand, and her rubies, emeralds, and diamonds are among the finest in England. She is fond of dogs, and may sometimes be seen walking with a big white boar hound.

The marriage of Captain Kenrick, of the 11th Hussars, and Miss Helen Little is now fixed for April 29, at St. Mary Abbott’s, Ken¬ sington. The bride will be given away by her brother, Mr. Arthur Little (of the 20th Hus¬ sars), and the best man will be Major Bailey (of the 11th Hussars), who is the second son of Lord Glanusk.
Mr. Drower, one of the directors of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd., arrived at Alexandria yesterday from Europe.
Mr. N. Kalomiris, F.R.C.S., has settled down in Alexandria.

div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
L'Encombrement des Quais
Interessante question de driot
div.p: The Commercial and Estates Cy. of Egypt, affréteur et en même temps destinataire, devait, aux termes de la charte partie, recevoir la cargaison transportée par le navire "Fos" en 20 jours à partir de l'arrivée et avis donné. Or le débarquement ayant été retardé par la Cie, la capitaine du “Fos", Ludwig Tupte, a attaqué The Commercial and Estates Cy. of Egypt en paiement des surestaries fixées dans la charte-partie à raison do 5 pence par tonne et par jour. Le retard ayant été de 17 jours 1/2, le montant de sa réclamation s'élevait ainsi à £576. The Commercial and Estates Cy. of Egypt plaidait le mal fondé de la demande et s’of- frait k prouver l' que malgré toutes les diligen- ces faites avant l’arrivée du “Fos”, il lui avait été impossible, à cause de l'encombrement du Port et du manque absolu de quais, d’obtenir do l’Administration du Port un quai pour son accostage avant le 27 janvier 1905, soit un mois apres l’arrivée du bateau 2nd que pendant les derniers mois, notamment pendant les mois do décembre 1904 et janvier 1905, il n’y avait pas de mahonnes ou d’allèges disponibles dans le port et 3rd qu'elle ne pouvait agir avec plus de diligence quelle n'a fait Le capitaine, de son cote reclamait simple- ment l’applicatioin du contrat d'affrètement qui a striotement prévu que la cargaison devait être reçue an port d’Alexaudrie en 20 jours, dimanches et fêtes exceptés. A la Compagnie qui affirmait que les jours de planche ne pou- vaieiit commencer à courir que du moment de l’accostagé du vapeur a quai, il répondait que l'art 9l 'invoqué n’était applicable que lorsque les jours de planche n’ont pas été fixés par le contrat, ce qui n’était pas le cas en l’espèce. Il contestait de plus le Cas de force majeure, prétexté par la compagnie. Le tribunal do commerce vient de con- damner The Commercial and Estates Cy. of Egypt à payer au capitaiue Tupte la somme de £ 576 avec les intérêts a 7 % a partir du jour de la demande ainsi qu’aux dépens. “ Attendu, dit le jugement, que cette con- vention spéciale qui forme la loi entre parties, est loin dé tomber sous l’empire des principes généraux on matière do surestaries aiusi que le soutient la défenderesse ; qu’au contraire elle constitue une notable dérogation ; que notam- ment le point de départ des jours de planche déterminés est l’avis donne de l’arrivée du navire ; qu’il n’y a aucune mention concernant un accostage a quai ni aucune référence aux usages les lieux quant au déchargement ; que la seule obligation incombant nu navire est de présenter la cargaison le long du bord en his- sant les marchandises hors cale ; qu’il résulte do tous ces éléments que l'inteution manifeste dés parties était de mettre a la charge des consignataires tous les risques inhérents à la réception; qu’en ces conditions la défende- resse no saurait opposer à la demande les dif- ficultés résultant de l'encombrement du port d'Alexandrie et du manque de mahonnes pour s’exonérer de la responsabilité pour les sures- taries mis à sa charge par la convention.

div.head: National Bank of Egypy
Avis
div.p: Messieurs las Actionnaires de la National Bank of Egypt sont convoqués en Assemblée Générale Ordinaire pour le Lundi vingt Mars 1905, a trois heures et demie de l'après-midi, au Siège Social, au Caire. ORDRE DU JOUR : Rapport du Conseil d’Administration. Rapport des Ceuseurs. Approbation des Comptes de l'exercice clos le 31 Décembre 1904. Fixation du dividende. Renouvellement partiel du Conseil d’Admi- nistration. Election des Censeurs pour l'exercice 1905. Fixation de l’indemnité des Censeurs. Tout actionnaire possédant au moius vingt actions a droit de prendre part à l’Assemblée Générale il condition de déposer ses actions dans l'un dos lieux ci-après désignés où il lui sera délivré une carte d'admission. En Egypte : Cinq jours au moins avant le jour de la réunion, soit le 15 Mars au plus tard : au Siège Social, au Caire, a la Succursale d’Alexandrie, aux Agences de la Banque il Assiout, Assouan, Benha, Beni Souef, Chibin-El- Kom, Damanhour, Fayum, 'Keneh, Man. sourah, Minieh, Port-Saïd, Sohag, Tantah, Zagazig et Musky (Caire. a l’Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Caire. à la Banque Impér. Ott., ou au Credit Lyonnais. a Alexandrie. a la Bank of Egypt. En Europe, au plus tard le 10 mars : à Paria et a Marseille, aux bureaux de la “Société Marseillaise", en Italie, dans les bu- reaux de la “Bauca Commerciale Italiana", a Londres, il l’Agence de la National Bank of Egypt, 4 et 5 King William Street. div.head: Reduced Rates on Sudan Government Railways and Steamers.
div.p: Labourers for Agricultural Purposes. A reduction of 3rd class passenger fares will granted to Landowners importing labourers for agricultural purposes under the following Conditions:— (а) A rebate of 20 per cent, will be granted upon the Sudan Government Steamers and Railways to all parties of agricultural labourers of not leas than 10 persons enter- ing the Sudan from Egypt on their journey from Aswan to any destination in the Sudan. (b) No rebate will bo allowed upon the fare for any local journey within the Sudan or upon any fare for a journey from the Sudan to Egypt. (c) No rebate will bo allowed on any ticket other than 3rd class. Rebates on 4th class fares cannot bo given. (d) In order to obtain the rebate, a receipt for the tickets issued must be obtained at the time the tickets are taken. (e) The rebate must be claimed at the end of each quarter from the Director of Rail- ways for the railway fares, and from the Director of Steamers and Boats for the steamer fares. All claims must bo supported by the re- ceipts mentioned in the precoding para- graph or they will not bo entertained. ( f ) All rebates will cease upon the opening of the Nile — Red Sea Railway to traffic. (g) In order to obtain the rebate a certificate must be obtained from the Agent General to the Sudan Government, War Office, Cairo, stating the name of the person importing the labourers (Landowner), the number of labourers, and their destination. 25405 12-A-9

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Ellerman S.S. “Alsatian” sailed hence on Saturday evening for Liverpool direct with general cargo, including 2,200 bales cotton. The Ellerman S.S. "Avon” arrived at Liver- pool on Saturday morning. The Westcott S.S. "Plymothian” sailed on Saturday for Syria. The Westcott S.S. "Egyptian” sailed from London on 20th inst. and is expected here with passengers and general cargo on or about 10th prox. The S.S. Creole Prince,” from Antwerp, left Middlesbrough on Friday, with passengers and general cargo for Malta and Alexandria. The Moss liner "Tabor" arrived here yes- terday evening from Liverpool, via Gibraltar Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo. The Moss liner “Rameses” sailed on Satur- day afternoon for Liverpool, via Malta, with passengers, mails, and general cargo, including 4,458 bales cotton. The Ellerman S.S. "Austrian” arrived today from Volos. The Westcott S.S. "Flavian" arrived today from Antwerp, London, and Malta with passen- gers and general cargo. The Messageries Maritimes S.S. "Niger,” from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday, andisdue here to-morrow morning.

British Chamber of Commerce.—We would call the attention of persons interested it: Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings, trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is £1 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad-street EC., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

div.head: Bourse Kdediviale
div.p: Remarques sur le marche du disponible et des contrats. Samedi, le 25 février 1905. Cotons Disponible.—Il n’y a pas eu énormément d’activité, si l’on veut, mais quand même, la demande a été bonne pour les qualités supé rieures qui ont profité d’une certaine hausse sur les prix. Les cotons inférieurs restent négligés. Franco Station.—On ne fait absolument rien, les prétentions de l’intérieur entravant les affaires. Contrats.—Nouvelle récolte. On s’y est beaucoup intéressé et, relativement aux se- maines précédentes, les transactions y ont été assez nombreuses. Quant aux prix, ils suivent tout naturellement les fluctuations de la vieille récolte et sont, au fond, très fermes. On dit que le Continent a fait quelques achats sur novembre. Récolte actuelle.—Les hauts et les bas ont été assez, fréquents et n'ont certainement pas nui A l’animation du marché. Actuellement, nous sommes sous l'influence de, l’Amérique, mais malgré tout, nous restons assez sou- tenus, avec de bonnes dispositions pour l’avenir. L’importance des exportations, dépas- saut toute attente, a été un bon élément pour les haussiers. Dans la matinée ; prix plus haut pour mars tal. 13 7/32 à —/—; plus bas pour mars 13 —/— A 1/32. Graines de coton Disponible.—Malgré les gros embarquements, la demande n’a rien eu d’extraordiuaire et la hausse do la semaine est dûe plutôt A la situation des contrats. Elle a été au total de P.T. 3 1/2. Franco-Gare.—Pas la moindre affaire. Contrats.—Nouvelle récolte. On n y fait que des'affaires occasionnelles, mais elle va A la remorque do la vieille récolte et c’est pour cette raison quelle monte. Récolte actuelle.—La hausse s'est accentuée et c’est Hull qui a donné le branle. On ditque les Indes signalent do sérieux dégât A la graine do lin et que l’Amérique no fait que monter sur les Huiles. Ici, il y a changement d’opinion, presque général, en fa veut de l’article. Dans la matinée ; prix plus liant pour le mars P.T. 59 5/40 A —]— ; plus bas pour le mars 57 25/40 A —/—. Feues Nullité complète sur toute la ligne et cote nominale, tant pour la nouvelle que pour l'ancienne récolte.

div.head: ARMY And NAVY
(From our Correspondent).
div.p: London, February 17. The S.S. “Dilwara” left Southampton to day with the 1st Battalion King's Own Light Infantry on board for Gibraltar and No. 2 Company R. G. A. and various drafts for Egypt The liner is due to arrive at Alexandria on the 4th prox.

Captain Harold D. Beamish, Leicestershire Regiment, who takes up duty with the Egyp- tian Army, served with the Mounted Infantry through the campaign of 1900-02 in the Transvaal and on the Swaziland border. He participated in over a dozen engagements under Buller, Major-General W. Kitchener, and Colonel Colville.
At the recent examinations abroad Lieut. C. W. Kemp, Royal Berkshire Regiment, Alex- andria, successfully passed for promotion to the rank of captain.

Whilst home on leave from India Captain Robert Frauds Warburton, a double company officier of the 2nd Battalion 5th Goorkha Rides, met with a horrible death. Captain Warburton, who was the son of the late Sir Robert War- burton, came from Abbolabad to England in January and stopped with his mother, Lady Warburton, in her apartments at Hampton Court Palace. The 20th inst. he left the palace as usual, and the following day his dead body was found ou the South Western Railway at Esher. From the appearance of the line it appeared that the unfortunate officer had been dragged along for a distance of over two miles. At the request yesterday an open verdict was returned.

Eighteen of the new 18 1/2-pounder field guns are to be despatched this month to India to re arm three field batteries, and 50 more will be despatched by the end of September. Sir Henry J. T. Hildyard, K.C.B., commanding the troops in South Africa, has urgently pressed On the Army Council the immediate necessity for re arming the field artillery in his command. It is understood that his request will be com- plied with os soon as possible.

In all eleven battleships, ten armoured cruisers, forty three cruisers, and sixty smaller ships, hulks, etc., are to he sold out of the Navy in consequence of the changes in naval policy initiated, there is every reason to believe, by Sir John Fisher, though some critics would have one believe that it is the work of the Admiralty as a whole. This enormous fleet of non effective ships represents an original out lay of no less than (Euro)17,247,075.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves for the responsible opinions expressed by our correspondents. but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to a11, to permit — within certain necessary limts — free dicussion
MISSIONS TO MOHAMEDANS.
To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir—I do not think that anyone can explain away the obvious meaning of the leading arti- cle in the “Gazette” on the above subject by merely bringing charges of “misrepresentation,” word-twisting,” and “cool impudence,” as a letter signed “Thos. Atwood” -does, against those with whom he does not happen to agree. There are considerable numbers of people who have been given a distinct impression, both by the article in question, and by various paragraphs that have recently appeared in your paper, that the “Gazette” is encouraging the notion that all religions (worthy of the name) are equally good and true, and that, rather than unreservedly accept the tenets of Christianity, a man should gather together out of the various religions all that pleases him in them, and then adopt these selections as his own creed. If we are all mistaken in our interpretation of the general intention of these passages, I for one shall be most sincerely relieved to hear it, by means of some direct declaration to that effect on the part of the writer of the articie in question. Up to now I Have been given no cause to withdraw anything I said in my former letter.

I cannot ask you, Sir, to give me space in which to reply at length to Mr. Atwood's letter, lor it seems to me that every paragraph in it ought to bo contested, and I am sure that he and I would both be equally bored by the time had done. May I say, however, that it is not easy to understand now questions (as the ad- visability of Christian missions to Moslems) possibly be discussed without bringing into them what be calls "the everlasting reli- gious difficulty,” lor it appears to mo that reli- gion is the very kernel of the whole subject. Indeed, my main object iu writing now is to say that I would never presume, by means of letters to the public press, to try and prove that Christian missions to Moslems are just- iciable , to those who hud that “Christianity is unable to satisfy their conceptions of eternal truth,” who say of Christ that “salvation .... is not alone to be found in Him, spite of all that certain passages in our English Bible convey,” and who cannot accept the Divine Sonship of our Lord. I fully understand that those who find themselves unable to accept the Bible as the Word of God, are at the same time naturally unable to recognise the em- phatic and binding nature of the command which Jesus has laid upon His own followers to preach the Gospel to every creature,” and that they need to be convinced of the absolute truth of Christianity before they can be ex- pected to believe in Christian missions.

I do not propose here to follow Mr. Atwood in his discussion of the claims of Christianity the failings of Christians, and I see that our standpoints with regard to the religious aspect of the question before us (Missions to Moslems) are so essentially different, that we cannot hope to convince each other by further correspondence in your hospitable columns.—I am, etc.,
R. Mai Innés.
2 .Sharia el Manakh, Cairo, February 24.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
Football.
div.p: THE SAINT ANDREW FOOTBALL CLUB versus "A.” COMPANY, ROYAL BERKS. The Saint Andrew Football Club opened their new ground on Moharrcm Bey common on Saturday week, when they had the “A" Company of the Royal Berks Regiment as their guests in their return game of the season. The game served up to the fair attendance of spectators was a good one, in spite of the wind, which at times upset the judgment of the players, and although the Berks were only playing 10 men. The Saints won the toss, and elected to play with the wind, but in spite of this advan- tage they failed to-score during the first half, and the teams turned round with the score nil. On resuming, the visitors took the game in hand, but, despite all efforts to notch a point they could not score. Bright, Cruise, and Keill were playing a nice defen- sive game, and Curtis in goal was always there when wanted. In this half the Saints' forwards could seldom get away, Edmunds and Kellor always bringing them up before they could get within shooting range of Gos- ling . Some corners against the Saints looked very dangerous, and Sayers placed well, but the Saints' defence relieved. From a kick out by Keil), Sweet got past and took the ball well up the field, passing at the right time to Tulloch, who in turn gave the ball to Jones, and this latter player very cleverly beat Gosling with a low raking shot. This reverse set the soldiers on their mettle, and they redoubled their efforts to score, but without avail, and time arrived with the Saints'victors by 1—0.
PORT SAID v. ZAGAZIG.

A football match was played on Friday, 24th inst, at 3.30 p.m., on the Telbasta market grounds, between the pupils of the Government schools of Port Said and Zagazig. It was a pleasant and exciting game, and resulted in a win for the latter school by 3 goals to none, The weather was fine and fairly warm, and a large number of visitors were present, among whom were the Moudir, Mr. and Mrs. Carver, and many well-known Europeans and natives, including Moh. Bey and Sedik Bey Abaza. Mr. Carter, Irrigation inspector, refereed. Preparations were made by Aly Bey Omar, head-master of Zagazig school, for the comfort of those who witnessed the game. The pupils of Port Said Government School and the head- master left the town by express train for Port Said, which was 50 minutes late.
LAWN TENNIS TOURNAMENT.

Les personnes qui connaissent les
Pilules du Docteur DEHAUT de Paris

n'hésitent pas à se purger, quand elles en ont besoin. Elles ne craignent ni le dégoût ni la fatigue, parce que, à l'opposé des autres purgatifs, celui-ci n'opère bien que lorsqu'il est pris avec de bons aliments et des boissons fortifiantes, telles que vin, café, thé. Chacun choisit, pour se purger, l'heure et le repas qui lui conviennent le mieux, selon ses occupations. La fatigue de la purgation étant annulée par l'effet de la bonne alimentation, on se décide aisément à recommencer autant de fois que cela est nécessaire.
